# How to Run locally the tsx file generated by claude.ai

Quick Setup

1. Initialize a new project:
   'bashmkdir my-project'
   'cd my-project'
   'npm init -y'
2. Install dependencies:
   npm install react react-dom
   npm install -D typescript @types/react @types/node vite
3. Create your TSX file:
   Save the Claude-generated code as App.tsx in your project folder.
4. Create an HTML entry point (index.html):
   <!DOCTYPE html>
   <html lang="en">
     <head>
       <meta charset="UTF-8" />
       <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
       <title>My App</title>
     </head>
     <body>
       <div id="root"></div>
       <script type="module" src="/main.tsx"></script>
     </body>
   </html>
5. Create an entry point (main.tsx):
   import React from 'react';
   import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
   import App from './App';

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')!).render(
<React.StrictMode>
<App />
</React.StrictMode>
); 6. Add Vite config (vite.config.ts):
import { defineConfig } from 'vite';

export default defineConfig({
esbuild: {
loader: 'tsx',
include: /src\/.\*\.tsx?$/,
},
}); 7. Update package.json scripts:
scripts": {
"dev": "vite",
"build": "vite build"
} 8. Run the development server:
npm run dev

Install Missing Dependencies
npm install lucide-react

Common Libraries Used by Claude Artifacts
Claude artifacts often use these libraries. Install any that your code needs:

# Icons

npm install lucide-react

# Charts

npm install recharts

# Utility libraries

npm install lodash mathjs

# Data visualization

npm install d3 plotly.js

# UI components (if using shadcn/ui)

npm install @radix-ui/react-alert-dialog @radix-ui/react-slot
npm install class-variance-authority clsx tailwind-merge

f Using Tailwind CSS
Many Claude artifacts use Tailwind. Set it up:
bashnpm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
npx tailwindcss init -p
Then configure tailwind.config.js:
javascriptexport default {
content: [
"./index.html",
"./src/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}",
"./*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}", // For root-level files
],
theme: {
extend: {},
},
plugins: [],
}
Add to your index.html or create a CSS file:
css@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;
Quick Fix Strategy

Look at the import statements in your TSX file
Install each missing library with npm install [package-name]
Restart your dev server (npm run dev)

Create a tsconfig.json file in your project root:
json{
"compilerOptions": {
"target": "ES2020",
"useDefineForClassFields": true,
"lib": ["ES2020", "DOM", "DOM.Iterable"],
"module": "ESNext",
"skipLibCheck": true,

    /* Bundler mode */
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "allowImportingTsExtensions": true,
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "isolatedModules": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "jsx": "react-jsx",

    /* Linting */
    "strict": true,
    "noUnusedLocals": true,
    "noUnusedParameters": true,
    "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true

},
"include": ["src", "*.tsx", "*.ts"],
"references": [{ "path": "./tsconfig.node.json" }]
}
The key setting is: "jsx": "react-jsx" (NOT "preserve")
Solution 2: Update vite.config.ts
Make sure your vite.config.ts looks like this:
typescriptimport { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
plugins: [react()],
});
Then install the React plugin:
bashnpm install -D @vitejs/plugin-react
Solution 3: Quick Fix - Rename Files
If the above doesn't work immediately, ensure:

Your files use .tsx extension (not .ts)
The entry point in index.html points to the correct file

Restart the Dev Server
After making these changes:
bash# Stop the current server (Ctrl+C)
npm run dev

Claude artifacts that use React components typically style themselves with Tailwind CSS utility classes. Here's how to get the styling working:
Option 1: Use Tailwind CDN (Quickest)
Add this to your index.html in the <head> section:
html<!DOCTYPE html>

<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
    <title>My App</title>
    <!-- Add Tailwind CDN -->
    <script src="https://cdn.tailwindcss.com"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="root"></div>
    <script type="module" src="/main.tsx"></script>
  </body>
</html>
This will make all Tailwind classes work immediately!
Option 2: Install Tailwind Properly (Recommended)
1. Install Tailwind:
bashnpm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
npx tailwindcss init -p
2. Configure tailwind.config.js:
javascriptexport default {
  content: [
    "./index.html",
    "./*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}",
    "./src/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}",
  ],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  plugins: [],
}
3. Create src/index.css:
css@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;
4. Import it in main.tsx:
tsximport React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import App from './App';
import './index.css'; // Add this line

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')!).render(
<React.StrictMode>
<App />
</React.StrictMode>
);
If the Artifact Uses Inline Styles
Some Claude artifacts include inline styles in a <style> tag within the component. These should work automatically without any CSS setup.
Check What Your File Uses
Look at your TSX file:

If you see className="bg-blue-500 text-white p-4" → Use Tailwind (Option 1 or 2)
If you see <style>{...}</style> inside the component → It should work as-is
If you see style={{color: 'red'}} → Inline styles work automatically
